misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel Arrays Stay Linked After Sorting One Array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will somehow remain aligned (or the correct "top" name will still be at index `n-1`).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `names` and `scores` are two separate arrays. `Arrays.sort(z)` only rearranges the elements inside `z`. It does not (and cannot) automatically rearrange `y` to keep name–score pairs together. If you want to keep pairs aligned, you must either swap both arrays in tandem during sorting, or combine name+score into one structure (e.g., a class/object) and sort that.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output / mismatched name with highest score (prints the last entered name, not necessarily the name belonging to the highest score).

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index Position Implies "Top Student" After Sorting (Ignoring Data Movement History)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting, the element at position `n-1` represents the top student in *both* arrays because "the top student is the last one".
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: It’s true that after sorting `z` ascending, `z[n-1]` is the maximum score. But `y[n-1]` is not the name of the student who earned `z[n-1]`; it’s just whatever name was originally read into the last slot. Java doesn’t track a hidden relationship like “this name belongs to that score” unless you explicitly maintain it.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output / logically inconsistent pairing like `Charlie (92)` when Charlie didn’t score 92.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when Arrays.sort() is called on one array (the scores), the corresponding elements in the parallel names array will somehow automatically move to maintain their original pairings. In other words, the student thinks that sorting the scores array will implicitly reorder the names array to keep each student's name with their score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not understand that Arrays.sort() is a static method that only modifies the array passed to it. It has no knowledge of parallel arrays or relationships between data in separate arrays. When z (scores) is sorted independently, y (names) remains in its original order. The indices no longer correspond correctly—the name at index n-1 is no longer paired with the score at index n-1. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of how parallel arrays must be maintained manually through paired index manipulation.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: wrong output - the program will print the last name in the original order paired with the highest score, rather than the name of the student who actually achieved that highest score. For the sample input, it would output 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)', since Charlie is at index 2 in names but 92 is now at index 2 in the sorted scores array.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores were entered into two arrays using the same indices, the computer perceives a permanent 'link' between these arrays. Therefore, if one array is reordered (sorted), the other array will automatically synchronize its elements to maintain those pairings.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects. The Arrays.sort() method is only aware of the specific array passed to it. It has no mechanism to identify or manipulate other arrays that the programmer might logically associate with the target array. To sort parallel arrays, the programmer must implement a manual sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) where swaps are performed on both arrays simultaneously, or use an Object-Oriented approach.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay aligned when one array is sorted
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if they sort the `scores` array, the corresponding `names` array will still match the same students (i.e., the pairing between `y[i]` and `z[i]` remains correct automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent containers. `Arrays.sort(z)` reorders only the elements of `z` (the scores). It does not know that `y` is “linked” to `z`, so it will not rearrange `y` to keep name–score pairs aligned. After sorting `z`, `z[i]` no longer corresponds to the original student in `y[i]` unless you also apply the same swaps/reordering to `y`.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed name may not be the student who actually achieved the printed top score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Index-based 'top student' assumption after sorting only scores
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting the scores, taking the last index `n-1` gives the top student’s name and score as a valid pair just by using the same index for both arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While `z[n-1]` will indeed be the highest score after sorting (ascending), `y[n-1]` is simply the last-entered name, not the name associated with the highest score. Using the same index in two arrays only preserves meaning if both arrays have been rearranged identically.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: often prints the last name entered with the highest score from someone else.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array (z) using `Arrays.sort(z)`, the correspondence between the names array (y) and the scores array (z) will be automatically maintained. They assume that after sorting, `y[n-1]` will still correspond to the student with the highest score in `z[n-1]`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort()` modifies only the array it is called on. Parallel arrays maintain their index-based correspondence through manual alignment—there is no implicit link between them. When you sort z but leave y unsorted, the indices no longer align correctly. After sorting z to [78, 85, 92], the name at y[2] is still 'Charlie', but z[2] is now 92 (which belonged to Bob). The student does not realize that simultaneous sorting (or tracking indices during sort) is required to keep parallel arrays synchronized.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output. The program prints an incorrect student name paired with the highest score. For the sample input, it outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)', because only the scores were sorted, not the names.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are conceptually linked (parallel arrays), performing a sort operation on one will automatically reorder the other to maintain the logical association between corresponding indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory objects. The Arrays.sort() method only operates on the specific array passed as an argument. It has no internal mechanism to 'know' that the element at y[i] is related to z[i]. To maintain the relationship, the programmer must implement a custom sorting algorithm that performs swaps on both arrays simultaneously, or use an Object-Oriented approach.
